Therefore , such differential impact should not hold in case analogical ability is normally distributed across the inventors of a target population . However , it is usual for inventor - level abilities to have a skewed - distribution ( see Ref . Singh and Fleming , 2010 ) and the same is true for general human abilities such creativity ( Sternberg and Grigorenko , 2003 ) . 12 , 13 Generally speaking , inventors with higher analogical ability will be able to exploit opportunities for exaptation sooner than inventors lack - ing this ability , already at low levels of technological complexity , whereas at high levels they will generally be better able to link a complex technology to new domains of use despite its complex - ity . In this way , inventors’ analogical ability will also strengthen , apart from an independent effect , the positive relationship between technological complexity and exaptation . Overall , a positive mod - eration effect means that for an inventor with greater analogical ability there is a sharper advantage ( more exaptive innovations ) in moving from low to medium levels of technological complexity : the left - side of the curvilinear relationship will increase more rapidly . Similarly , for an inventor with greater analogical ability there is a sharper advantage in moving from medium to high levels of tech - nological complexity : the right - side of the curvilinear relationship will decrease more slowly . Patent scope Exaptation also follows from the possibility to build on a tech - nology whose successive developments are not protected by patent scope . We deﬁne patent scope as the size of the set of hypotheti - cal developments of the technology that , together with the main conﬁguration , are also subject to patent protection . Patent scope is the set of hypothetical ‘embodiments’ of the technology that were originally envisioned by the inventors , and can be likened to the fence around a real property : it distinguishes inventors’ intellectual property from the surrounding ‘terrain’ of technological possibili - ties ( Merges and Nelson , 1990 ) . Patent scope acts as an important institutional condition that shapes successive technological devel - opments ( Kitch , 1977 ; Merges and Nelson , 1990 ) . In particular , it plays an important role for those technologies whose develop - ments can proceed on alternative trajectories ( Merges and Nelson , 1990 ) . As argued by Bonaccorsi ( 2011 ) , the greater the patent scope , the stronger the monopoly power granted to the technology owner and the fewer the incentives for other ﬁrms to develop a new tech - nology that may infringe on the old one . Indeed Klemperer ( 1990 ) and Gilbert and Shapiro ( 1990 ) have argued that patent scope is a positive input of an innovator’s proﬁt function . Reitzig ( 2003 ) has argued that patent scope is a ‘value driver’ , and Lerner ( 1994 ) has found that patent scope increases the value of biotech ﬁrms . Other economists , on the other hand , have stressed the negative aspects 12 The idea that human abilities are normally distributed can be reconducted to Galton : after Galton’s contribution , the normal distribution had become a dogma in many statistical frameworks adopted by psychologists . We hypothesize that the extension of patent scope limits the incentive of inventors to modify a decomposable technology and explore new exaptive options . This is consistent with the idea that patent scope blocks successive technological developments ( Kitch , 1977 ; Merges and Nelson , 1990 ) . This has two implications . First , patent scope has a direct negative effect on exaptation . Second , it could negatively moderate the inverted U - shaped relation - ship between technological complexity and exaptation . Generally speaking , at low levels of technological complexity , technologies with higher patent scope will decrease opportunities for exapta - tion by inventors than those technologies with lower patent scope . Whereas , at high levels of technological complexity , technologies with higher patent scope will expose downstream inventors to a larger set of missed opportunities for exaptation than those tech - nologies with low patent scope . Overall , a negative moderation effect means that those technologies with greater patent scope are characterized by a sharper disadvantage ( less exaptive innovations ) moving from low to medium levels of technological complexity : the left - side of the curvilinear relationship will increase more slowly . Similarly , those technologies with greater patent scope are char - acterized by a sharper disadvantage moving from medium to high levels of technological complexity : the right - side of the curvilinear relationship will decrease more rapidly . H4 . Patent scope negatively affects exaptation . H5 . Patent scope negatively moderates the inverted U - shaped relationship between technological complexity and exaptation . 3 . Methods 3 . 1 . Data In order to test our hypotheses , we studied exaptation at the invention level ; we identiﬁed an invention with a patent and considered a cross - section of U . S . patents . Raw patent data were obtained from the USPTO and NBER databases ( Hall et al . , 2001 ) , and the main measures were built after merging these databases to the Patent Network Dataverse ( Lai et al . , 2011 ) . Patent data allowed us to exploit the information contained in forward citations and in the classiﬁcation system , which proved particularly useful . Forward citations not only reﬂect the replication around the ‘prior art’ of an invention , they also reﬂect the extension of the prior art in novel technological domains ( Sorenson et al . , 2006 ) . This is demonstrated by the fact that , quite often , forward citations come from different technological classes ( Ghiglino and Kuschy , 2010 ) . We refer to them as ‘cross - class’ forward citations . Overall , our empirical framework builds on the work of Fleming and Sorenson ( 2001 ) ( see also Refs . : Fleming , 2001 ; Singh and Fleming , 2010 ; Sorenson et al . , 2006 ) . That empirical treatment is a ﬁrst attempt in the innovation literature to deal with issues such as technological complexity . Our empirical framework consisted of the following steps : ( 1 ) we considered a random cross - section of U . S . patents granted between January and June 1991 ( both the January – June interval and the year 1991 were chosen randomly ) ; ( 2 ) for each patent we used a 1991 – 1999 window of forward citations to calculate exaptation ; ( 3 ) for each patent we then con - sidered a 1975 – 1990 pre - sample window in order to calculate technological complexity , inventor’s analogical ability , and other controls . The estimation sample consists of 19076 patents . 1424 M . Mastrogiorgio , V . Gilsing / Research Policy 45 ( 2016 ) 1419 – 1435 3 . 2 . Measures 3 . 2 . 1 . Exaptation Exaptation always implies two aspects : the ‘functional shift’ of an existing invention , and a certain degree of ‘non - anticipation’ , as the functional shift cannot always be envisioned ex - ante . Our novel measure of exaptation tries to capture both aspects . In order to capture the functional shift , we built on the fact that forward citations often come from different technological classes ( Ghiglino and Kuschy , 2010 ) . This means that forward citations often reﬂect the extension of an invention in novel technological domains ( Sorenson et al . , 2006 ) . We assumed that cross - class forward cita - tions reﬂect the co - option of an invention for novel functions . We therefore assumed that different technological classes iden - tify different functions , and this is consistent with the classiﬁcation system developed by the USPTO . 14 In order to capture non - anticipation , we built on the fact that the USPTO assigns a patent to several classes : an OR class , which is mandatory and reﬂects the most comprehensive claim or main function of the invention , and XR classes , which may reﬂect alterna - tive applications envisioned when the patent was granted ( USPTO , 2012a , b ) . If both the OR and XR classes of the focal patent differed from the OR class of the citing patent ( at the three - digit level ) , we assumed that the functional shift was not originally envisioned when the focal patent was granted . We considered only the OR and not the XR class of the citing patent as we were only interested in the main function of the citing technology , and compared it to the main and other envisioned function of the cited technology . Overall , our measure of exaptation is based on the proportion of cross - class forward citations . In our setting , a forward citation is cross - class if both the OR and XR classes of the focal patent differ from the OR class of the citing patent . Therefore , exaptation for patent i is given by : y i = N (cid:2) j = 1 d j N ( 1 ) where N is the number of forward citations received until the end of 1999 , and d j is a dummy equal to 1 if the both the OR and XR classes of patent i differ from the OR class of the citing patent j ( 0 otherwise ) . Therefore , our measure differs from patent generality indexes ( Trajtenberg et al . , 1997 ) used in a variety of studies in order to identify general - purpose technologies . These indexes , also based on the range of technology ﬁelds that cite the focal patent , are only based on OR classes . Fig . 1 contains a graphical illustration . According to the fourth and ﬁfth hypothesis , patent scope blocks technological developments pursued by different ﬁrms and , there - fore , also plays a negative moderating role in the relationship between technological complexity and exaptation . Technological complexity We measured technological complexity as in Fleming and Sorenson ( 2001 ) ( see also Ref . Sorenson et al . , 2006 ) . The measure is based on the degree of difﬁculty of recombining – in a pre - sample window – the subclasses of which the patent is composed . The underlying assumption is that patent subclasses are proxies of underlying components , which can be physical components or pieces of knowledge only indirectly connected to physical conﬁg - urations ( Sorenson et al . , 2006 ) . The idea behind the measure is that if the patent is composed of subclasses that , in the past , could not be easily re - combined with many other subclasses , this is an indication of the fact that components are characterized by sensi - tive interdependencies and their actual conﬁguration belongs to a small set of possible alternative conﬁgurations . This kind of patent receives a high value of technological complexity . Conversely , if the patent is composed of subclasses that , in the past , could be re - combined easily with many other subclasses , this is an indication of the fact that components are not characterized by sensitive inter - dependencies and they can be mixed and matched independently . In other words , their actual conﬁguration belongs to a large set of possible alternative conﬁgurations . This kind of patent receives a low value of technological complexity . Therefore , we measured the technological complexity of patent i as follows : x i = cs i (cid:3) cs i j = 1 er j ( 3 ) where cs i is the number of subclasses of patent i , and er j is the ‘ease of recombination score’ of each subclass j . In other words , we mea - sured the technological complexity of patent i as the inverse of the average ease of subclass recombination . The ease of recombination of a generic subclass j is given by : er j = N sc , j N pat , j ( 4 ) where N sc , j is the number of subclasses that appeared with sub - class j in N pat , j previous patents . As mentioned before , Fleming and Sorenson ( 2001 ) deﬁned technological complexity as the interac - tion of interdependence and the number of subparts . Inventors’ analogical ability The ability of inventors to draw inventive analogies and exapt existing technologies across different domains is a function of their stock of knowledge spanning these domains . We introduced a novel measure of inventors’ analogical abilities that quantiﬁes their multi - domain skills . In order to build the measure , we considered the inventor ( or team ) belonging to the ﬁrst citing patent . We then extracted , from the Patent Network Dataverse ( Lai et al . , 2011 ) , the inventor’s previous patents that belong to the 1975 – 1990 pre - sample window . We then counted the number of previous patents whose OR class was equal to the OR class of either the focal patent or the citing patent . It could be argued that an inventor has a high value on the count by simply having deep experience in either the OR class of the focal patent or that of the citing patent , rather than having equally - distributed experience in both classes . This type of consideration could make us lean toward a product - based rather than a sum - based measure . A product - based measure would be equal to zero in the case of an inventor having deep experience in one class and zero experience in the other . This would some - how correspond to claiming that analogical ability – and its effect on exaptive technological breakthroughs – equals zero in deep experience cases . However , some recent research has emphasized the dual dimension of technological breakthroughs—as they may require bridging diverse knowledge domains as well as a deep knowledge of a particular knowledge domain ( see Ref . Kaplan and Vakili , 2014 ) . A general example is provided by how Ford borrowed the idea of the moving assembly line from the meatpacking indus - try in Chicago . Ford had deep experience in handcrafting a car ( in his garage ) but no experience at all in meatpacking . The example clearly shows that if we would rely on a product - based measure then we would qualify inventors such as Ford as having no analogy making abilities , whereas the example shows that deep experience in one domain can still enable analogical processes . Therefore , we opted towards a more generic count - based measure and at the same time we controlled for all those cases of deep experience ( see the ‘concentration dummy’ in the controls section ) . Overall , our measure is more speciﬁc than knowledge diversity measures in the sense that it only captures the accumulation of knowledge in the target and base domains , which is a condition for the emergence of cognitive mappings or analogies between these domains . More - over , in order to exclude other equally plausible mechanisms at the individual level , we introduce several controls such as knowledge diversity , past experience in more than two technological areas , inventive myopia ( see Section 3 . 2 . 5 ) . Inventors’ data have several limitations , such as the lack of a unique identiﬁcation of inventors due to name ambiguity on patent records , and eventual missing data due to randomness of disambiguation algorithms ( Lai et al . , 2011 ) . Therefore , we dropped those cases in which the citing patent had no inventor identiﬁcation , and controlled for those cases in which the citing patent had one or more inventors with no previous patents . 1426 M . Patent scope We introduced the number of patent claims as a proxy of patent scope . A patent includes a set of claims , where the principal claim describes the essential characteristics of the invention while the subordinate claims deﬁne more detailed characteristics or alter - native hypothetical ‘embodiments’ of the invention . As argued by Lanjouw and Schankerman , ( 2001 ) , patent claims deﬁne the scope of legal protection of a technology . As noted by Merges and Nelson ( 1990 ) , they form a protective line around the patent that delim - its inventors’ intellectual property from the surrounding terrain of technological possibilities . This interpretation is particularly valid in patent - law systems known as ‘peripheral’ ( US , UK , and Japan ) : in those systems the entire set of claims ‘exactly’ deﬁnes the ‘fence’ of protection ( Fromer , 2009 ) . In patent - law systems known as ‘cen - tral’ ( Germany and continental Europe ) , on the other hand , only few embodiments deﬁne protection , and those are used to determine whether potentially infringing items are ‘similar enough’ to them . It is important to note that the patent applicant usually has an incen - tive to claim as much as possible , although the patent examiner may require the number of claims to be narrowed before granting ( Lanjouw and Schankerman , 2001 ) . 3 . 2 . 5 . Control variables We introduced several controls in order to rule out unobserved factors that may be correlated with technological complexity and , at the same time , with exaptation ( see also Refs . Fleming and Sorenson , 2001 ; Fleming , 2001 ; Singh and Fleming , 2010 ; Sorenson et al . , 2006 ) . 3 . 2 . 5 . 1 . Inventors’ generic experience . A patent may be less exaptive not because of greater technological complexity , but because the inventor that builds on the patent has less prior generic experience . We used , as a proxy of generic experience , the number of previous patents of the inventor ( or team ) of the ﬁrst patent that cites the focal patent i ( Singh and Fleming , 2010 ) . Previous patents belong to a 15 - year pre - sample window ( 1975 – 1990 interval ) . 3 . 2 . 5 . 2 . Inventors’ diversity of experience . A patent may be less exaptive not because of greater technological complexity , but because the inventor ( or team ) has less prior experience with differ - ent technological areas . We used , as a proxy of experience diversity , the number of technological classes in which the inventor ( or team ) of patent i had previous patents ( Singh and Fleming , 2010 ) . Previous patents belong to a 15 - year pre - sample window . M . Mastrogiorgio , V . Gilsing / Research Policy 45 ( 2016 ) 1419 – 1435 1427 3 . 2 . 5 . 3 . Inventors’ team dummy . A patent may be less exaptive not because of greater technological complexity , but because the inven - tor that builds on the patent is working alone and has no access to creative collaboration . We controlled for those cases in which the inventors of the ﬁrst citing patent belong to a team . 3 . 2 . 5 . 4 . Inventors’ team size . Adopting a similar logic , we also con - trolled for the size of the team . 3 . 2 . 5 . 5 . Concentration dummy . As mentioned above ( see analogy measure ) , we controlled for those cases in which the inventor ( or team ) belonging to the ﬁrst citing patent had previous patents all concentrated in the OR class of either the cited patent or the citing patent . 3 . 2 . 5 . 6 . Inventors’ control . As mentioned above , we also controlled for those cases in which the ﬁrst citing patent had one or more inventors with no previous patents . 3 . 2 . 5 . 7 . Combination familiarity . A patent may be less exaptive not because of greater technological complexity , but because the inven - tor ( or team ) that builds on the patent has excessive familiarity with its conﬁguration of components and remains trapped in local search ( March 1991 ) . In order to measure familiarity with the con - ﬁguration of components of patent i , we measured the average time proximity of patent i to previous patents having an identical con - ﬁguration of patent subclasses ( Fleming , 2001 ) . Previous patents belong to a 15 - year pre - sample window . 3 . 2 . 5 . 8 . Number of subclasses . A patent may be less exaptive not because of greater technological complexity , but because the inven - tor ( or team ) that builds on the patent has to deal with its excessive number of components , and this may represent a cognitive bound . We used the number of patent subclasses as a proxy for the number of components ( Fleming , 2001 ) . 3 . 2 . 5 . 9 . Single subclass dummy . Several patents in our sample have only one subclass—around 7 % . As the technological complexity measure is not able to capture interdependencies for those patents , we controlled for them ( Fleming and Sorenson , 2001 ) . 3 . 2 . 5 . 10 . Number of prior art citations . A patent may be less exap - tive not because of greater technological complexity , but because it is characterized by higher technological maturity that limits the exploration of exaptive reconﬁgurations . We used the number of backward citations as a proxy of technological maturity ( Ziedonis , 2007 ) . 3 . 2 . 5 . 11 . Scientiﬁc references . A patent may be less exaptive not because of greater technological complexity , but because it is char - acterized by lower levels of generality . We used the number of non - patent references ( e . g . to scientiﬁc journals ) as a proxy of gen - erality . Moreover , non - patent references are also an indirect proxy of technological maturity , as patents with more scientiﬁc refer - ences tend to protect early - stage inventions ( Narin et al . , 1997 ) . 3 . 2 . 5 . 12 . Technology control . We controlled for the average number of citations received by previous patents in the same technological class of patent i , in order to remove systematic sources of varia - tion in the citation process that may affect our dependent variable ( Fleming and Sorenson ( 2001 ) ) . If patent i falls into different tech - nological classes , we also included those classes in the calculation , as in Ref . Fleming and Sorenson ( 2001 ) . 3 . 2 . 5 . 13 . Number of classes . We included this variable because a patent that falls into a broad range of technological classes is more likely to be cited by future patents , and this may affect the denom - inator of our dependent variable ( Fleming and Sorenson , 2001 ) . Similarly , a patent that falls into a broad range of technological classes is more likely to be cited by patents that also fall into dif - ferent technological classes . This may affect the numerator of our dependent variable . 3 . 2 . 5 . 14 . Diversity of patent portfolio . In order to test the ﬁfth hypothesis , we looked at how much ‘cross - ﬁrm’ forward citations spread across different technological classes . We wanted to rule out those factors that may depend on the propensity of ﬁrms’ patent portfolios to cite patents belonging to different technologi - cal classes . We therefore used pre - sample information to measure ﬁrm characteristics . According to Blundell et al . ( 1995 ) , this means including variables that approximate the accumulation of a ﬁrm’s technological knowledge and it may constitute an approxima - tion of unobservable factors . For each forward citation received by the focal patent i , we calculated the technological diversity of the patent portfolio belonging to the citing patent’s ﬁrm . We then calculated average technological diversity across all forward citations and introduced it as a control . In order to calculate tech - nological diversity , we computed a Herﬁndahl index of dispersion across technological classes of the ﬁrm’s previous patents . We also controlled for the technological diversity of the patent portfolio belonging to the ﬁrm of the focal patent i . We considered a 10 - year pre - sample window in order to calculate these measures . 3 . 2 . 5 . 15 . Size of patent portfolio . Adopting a similar logic , we con - trolled for the average size of the patent portfolio belonging to the citing patents’ ﬁrms , and for the size of the patent portfolio belonging to the ﬁrm of the focal patent i . 3 . 2 . 5 . 16 . Technological class ﬁxed effects . We introduced technolog - ical class ﬁxed effects to remove systematic sources of variation in the citation process that may take place across technological classes and be missed by the ‘technology control’ . 3 . 2 . 5 . 17 . Application year and citing year ﬁxed effects . We controlled for the application year of the focal patent and for the applica - tion years of the ﬁrst and last citing patents to remove systematic sources of variation in the citing process that may take place over time . While , at ﬁrst sight , citing year ﬁxed effects may appear endogenous to the exaptation process , they have been recently adopted for the econometric identiﬁcation of the age proﬁle of patent citations ( see Ref . Mehta et al . , 2010 ) . As noted by Mehta et al . ( 2010 : 1180 ) , ‘controlling for the birth year of the citing patent ( deﬁned as “calendar effect” ) is important because patents have received more citations in recent years , reﬂecting an overall increase in patenting’ . As double - check , we removed citing year ﬁxed effects from some models speciﬁcations and the main results did not change substantially . 15 3 . 2 . 5 . 18 . Grant month ﬁxed effects . Case - control design Our current approach , based on the aggregation of citing patents into a single measure , precludes the possibility to control for the heterogeneity of citing patents and , therefore , of future inventors . This may explain the lack of support of hypotheses such as H3 . Therefore , as in Ref . Sorenson et al . ( 2006 ) , we introduced a case - control design in order to better control for the heterogeneous attributes of future inventors and avoid the potential biases that may result from aggregating them into a single measure . Our new analysis treated the focal patent - citing patent dyad as the unit of analysis rather than the focal patent as before . Our case - control procedure worked as follows . First , we started from our initial sample of patents granted between January and June 1991 and identiﬁed those 12334 focal patents that received at least one non - anticipated cross - class citation as explained above—that is , we considered those focal patents that received citations from OR classes that differ from both the OR and XR classes of the focal patent itself ( we considered the 1991 – 1999 window for citations ) . Second , we built the dyads by pairing the focal patent with each cross - class citation and set the dependent variable equal to 1 for these realized dyads . Third , we paired the focal patent with three future citations that did not cite the focal patent but that could have cited it , since these citations also cite patents belonging to differ - ent technological classes . We therefore set the dependent variable equal to 0 for these unrealized dyads of the control group . 17 We chose three citations for the control group so that the sample would have a similar proportion of realized and unrealized dyads , since a focal patent receives three cross - class citations on average . Over - all , the sample contains a total of 77166 realized and unrealized dyads . As our dependent variable has a value of 1 or 0 for realized and unrealized dyads respectively , we adopted logistic regression . However , the use of a case - control design usually introduces new problems such as biased estimates of the logistic regression due to lack of independence across repeated observations due to the repeated entry of focal patents in the data . Discussion , implications and conclusions Overall , our ﬁndings show that the creation potential for exap - tive innovations is correlated to three main conditions . A ﬁrst condition is the degree of technological complexity . The curvilinear effect of technological complexity implies that , to the extent that technological interdependencies between components increase , the exaptation potential is observed to go up . However , our ﬁnd - ings also indicate that this works only up to a point , because when complexity becomes too high , the exaptation potential is observed to diminish . Overall , our results show that our main hypothesis of the curvilinear relationship between technological complexity and exaptation is conﬁrmed . A second condition is the degree of ana - logical ability—i . e . the cognitive ability of certain inventors to see commonalities between seemingly unrelated domains . Inventors’ analogical ability is positively correlated to exaptive innovation . These results are consistent with the general argument that anal - ogy making plays a central role during the process of invention ( Hargadon and Sutton , 1997 ) . More speciﬁcally , these results res - onate with the argument that exaptive events are produced by cognitive processes which consist in establishing relations – or mappings – among different problem domains ( Furnari , 2011 ) . However – with the exception of the case - control design spec - iﬁcations – we could not ﬁnd clear statistical support for our hypothesis that inventors’ analogical ability positively moderates the relationship between technological complexity and exaptive innovation . This result is puzzling , because it suggests that the prior knowledge owned by inventors is positively correlated to exaptive innovation but not because it helps them to arrive at a richer representation of the architecture of the inventive problem and to better process complex interdependencies ( Gavetti et al . , 2005 ) . As argued by Gavetti et al . ( 2005 ) , we believe that this link - age between inventors’ analogical ability and the architecture of the inventive problem is a crucial aspect that future studies should explore more carefully . Also , we could not ﬁnd statistical support for our hypotheses that patent scope has a direct and moder - ating effect on exaptive innovation . This result is surprising but not puzzling , and may be explained as follows . If patent scope is larger , inventors may experience a stronger incentive to look for new application domains that fall beyond the claims speciﬁed in the patent . While larger patent scope may indeed block innova - tions that fall within the scope claimed by the focal patent , at the same time it may stimulate innovations that fall beyond this scope . This seems to suggest that patent scope blocks more incre - 21 The differences between predicted probabilities for given intervals of complex - ity reﬂect the estimated coefﬁcient of complexity for those intervals and can be thus used to enhance the representation of non - monothonic effects . This is consistent with some recent studies that contradict the widespread argument that patent scope blocks downstream technological developments . For example , Katznelson and Howells ( 2012 ) have analysed the activity directed at ‘designing - around’ Edison’s patent of the incan - descent lamp . They have demonstrated that the legal enforcement of Edison’s patent stimulated several downstream developments of major technological importance , some of which were directed to design around Claim 2 of Edison’s patent ( the hardest claim to circumvent at the time ) . We suggest this as an issue for future research . Although we cannot establish relationships of the causal type , our results point to a number of practical implications both for ﬁrms and for policy makers . A ﬁrst implication is that , to the extent that ﬁrms want to stimulate the potential for exaptive innovations , it becomes critical to measure the degree of complexity of the tech - nologies in their portfolio as complexity inﬂuences the potential for successful exaptation . For instance , our results suggest that R & D managers should measure the degree of complexity of the patents in their portfolio . Then they should calibrate the patent portfolio – e . g . through patent acquisitions or divestitures – in a way that it contains patents whose average complexity is around the optimal value of 10 . This would increase the portfolio - level potential for exaptation and , more importantly , it could have positive indirect consequences such as increasing revenues in case the ﬁrm plans to sell or out - license the patents . Our results also provide an indica - tion of the level of complexity that engineers should target , as they search for an optimal level of modularization that increases the potential for exaptative innovations . A second implication is that increasing the potential for an innovation through exaptation will not so much follow from spending more on R & D nor from inten - sifying current technological search efforts . The effect of inventor analogy making indicates that exaptation stems from different cog - nitive processes when compared to adaptive innovation , and they reveal the fallacies of dominant mindsets and strongly held beliefs such as industry recipes ( Spender , 1989 ) . Hence , the fundamental point is that exaptations are less likely to originate from in - depth technological expertise , but instead from what could be more gen - erally qualiﬁed as ‘analogy making ability’ . Typically for ﬁrms with deep expertise in their core business activities is that they rely on in - depth experts who think within their deep pockets of expertise , whereas they simply forget looking ‘to the side’ and see what has already been invented or where new application domains reside for their current expertise and technology . In addition , this risk may not only rest within R & D and with its specialists but also at higher echelons within ﬁrms . A case in point is formed by Polaroid that was the ﬁrst company to develop a digital camera in its R & D labs . However , senior management qualiﬁed this as a failure because it did not recognize its potential for application in new domains and the creation of new markets . Instead , they clang to their exist - ing business model that prescribed revenues to come from selling ﬁlm rather than from selling ( new ) hardware , which ultimately led to their demise in the early 1990s . So the key implication for ﬁrms is that , to address this risk of limited analogy making abil - ity , boosting their innovation performance may also come from challenging established beliefs and dominant cognitions that may serve as a formidable barrier to exaptive innovation . To address this risk , ﬁrms can take several measures . One is that ﬁrms should cherish the mavericks in their organizations to the extent that they carry the ability to see things or opportunities well before any - one else does . A second one is to systematically hire people from other industries who can see opportunities for application in their industry of origin much sooner and will be better qualiﬁed to assess their attractiveness . A third measure is formed by engaging in sys - tematic inter - sectoral collaboration rather than in intra - sectoral 1434 M . Mastrogiorgio , V . Gilsing / Research Policy 45 ( 2016 ) 1419 – 1435 collaboration . Whereas inter - sectoral collaboration comes at a ( ini - tial ) price of overcoming a larger cognitive distance with the involved partner ( s ) , it also carries the potential of yielding innova - tions with much higher novelty value , once cognitive distance has been overcome ( Nooteboom et al . , 2007 ; Gilsing et al . , 2008 ) . What these three measures share is their common emphasis on nurtur - ing a sense of ‘cognitive openness’ that contributes to the ability of analogy making . For policy makers , the implication is that a classi - cal instrument in their tool - box formed by stimulating private R & D through ﬁscal measures is especially relevant for the more main - stream , ‘classical’ recombination process formed by technological search activities in view of adaptation . However , to stimulate inno - vation and renewal in an economy through the alternative process of exaptation , it is critical to stimulate cognitive openness by ﬁrms . Policy makers can enhance this by ensuring , among others , an easy and free ﬂow of people across different industries ( e . g . limiting anti - competition clauses in labor contracts ) , but also through reduction or elimination of barriers for foreign knowledge workers for entry . In addition , a risk that policy makers should be aware of is that they are being exposed to lobbying through players from estab - lished industries with vested interests in maintaining the status quo ( Aldrich and Fiol , 1994 ) . This is typically how established play - ers respond to disruptive technologies and innovations , instead of by changing the focus and speed of their own innovation activi - ties . Instead , they tend to rely on ‘regulatory capture’ formed by lobbying and inﬂuencing policy makers in order to maintain the status quo and withstand the possible disruption of their indus - try , through an exaptative innovation from elsewhere . Hence , an awareness of this risk and a similar degree of cognitive openness may be critical for policy makers to stimulate innovation through exaptation in the economy . Our paper has several limitations . First , our main empirical set - ting was based on a cross - sectional sample of patents . In order to rule out eventual unobserved heterogeneity , the identiﬁcation strategy proposed by Mehta et al . ( 2010 ) – which is based on the exploitation of the patent grant lag as a source of exogenous variation – may represent a starting point for future studies that will adopt a similar empirical setting . Second , our novel mea - sure may be coarse in the sense that – besides exaptations – it may capture a subset of functional shifts that are due to differ - ent technological characteristics such as ‘generality’ . Although our measure differs from generality ( see Section 3 . 2 . 1 ) and we con - trol for it ( see Section 3 . 2 . 5 ) , there is still room for improvement . We leave this to future research . Overall , cross - class forward cita - tions are systematic ( Ghiglino and Kuschy , 2010 ) and they may reﬂect the pervasivity of technological exaptation ( Dew et al . , 2004 ; Kauffmann , 2000 ) . Third , our empirical setting was based on patent data , which are characterized by several shortcomings . The accuracy of patent measures can vary signiﬁcantly across technolo - gies . For instance , patent subclasses may not always correspond to underlying technological components ( Fleming and Sorenson , 2001 ) . Future research should explore these measurement issues more deeply . Fourth , complementary explanations of our main results should be also considered . For instance , some results in Table 3 - C such as a stronger effect of the squared term seem to suggest that inventors of different versus focal ﬁrms are more sub - ject to the negative impact of high level of complexity . This may be due to lower communication advantages – and lower ﬂows of use - ful information – due to lower social proximity to the inventors of the focal ﬁrm ( see Ref . Sorenson et al . , 2006 ) . Similarly , some results in Table 3 - C suggest that , when patent scope increases , inventors of different versus focal ﬁrms experience a stronger ‘incentive’ to look for new application domains that fall beyond the claims speciﬁed in the patent , and this may stimulate exaptive innovation . Alterna - tive explanations should not be ruled out , such as lower cognitive barriers due to organizational differences . Future research should explore these issues more deeply . Despite these limitations , our paper offers several contribu - tions . First , our ﬁndings contribute to the general debate on the emergence of radical innovations – and on variety creation in the economy – by further illuminating the role played by exap - tive mechanisms . In this regard , we shed light on the existence of underlying ‘systematic’ conditions that foster exaptive mech - anisms . Second , our empirical results shed light on a number of speciﬁc theoretical arguments that have been made very recently in the exaptation literature , in particular that literature that has analysed the role of exaptation and modularization ( Andriani and Carignani , 2014 ) . Third , our paper brings new insights into the broad debate on technological evolution and evolutionary analo - gies ( Arthur , 2009 ; Nelson and Winter , 1982 ) . Fourth , our ﬁndings contribute to the debate on how innovation is shaped by exap - tive and adaptive mechanisms . The concept of ‘exaptation’ , which implies a sudden functional shift of a technology , has been intro - duced to make a distinction from the concept of ‘adaptation’ , which implies a gradual process driven by selective pressures . The conditions that lead to adaptation have been analysed in a com - prehensive manner : see Fleming and Sorenson’s ‘Technology as a Complex Adaptive System ’ ( 2001 ) . Our paper adopts a similar empirical framework in order to ﬁll a gap and explore the conditions of exaptive mechanisms that foster new innovations . .
